Utterance: Hi! Welcome back! How has your week been? Were you able to practice mindfulness?
Hi, Ellie! Yes, I actually tried it a few times. It was nice to just take a moment for myself.
That’s fantastic! How did it feel to take that time for yourself?
It felt refreshing. I didn’t realize how much I needed it until I did it. I felt more relaxed afterward.
That’s great to hear! Mindfulness can really help in managing stress. Did you notice any changes in your mood or interactions with others after practicing?
I think I was a bit more patient with my daughter. I didn’t get as frustrated as I usually do when she was being a handful.
That’s a wonderful outcome! It sounds like you’re starting to see the benefits of mindfulness in your parenting. How has it affected your feelings of overwhelm?
It’s helped a lot. I’m starting to realize that I don’t have to be perfect all the time.
That’s an important realization. Perfection is an unrealistic expectation. What do you think is a more attainable goal for you as a parent?
I guess just being present for her and doing my best. That feels more achievable.
Absolutely! Being present is one of the best gifts you can give her. Have you had any challenges this week that you’d like to discuss?
Yes, actually. I had a disagreement with my husband about finances, and it escalated quickly.
I’m sorry to hear that. Disagreements can be tough. How did you handle it?
I tried to stay calm, but I ended up raising my voice. I felt like he wasn’t listening to my concerns.
It’s understandable to feel frustrated when you feel unheard. What do you think triggered that reaction in you?
I think it’s just the stress of everything piling up. I worry about money a lot, especially with my daughter’s needs.
That’s a valid concern. Financial stress can weigh heavily on anyone. Have you thought about ways to communicate your concerns to your husband in a calmer way?
Not really. I usually just blurt it out when I’m upset. Maybe I should try to express my feelings before it gets to that point.
That’s a great idea! Expressing your feelings before they escalate can lead to more productive conversations. Would you like to practice some ways to approach that?
Sure, I’d like that.
Let’s think of a few phrases you could use when you feel overwhelmed. For example, “I’m feeling stressed about our finances, and I’d like to talk about it.” How does that sound?
That sounds good. I can see how that might help set a calmer tone.
Exactly! It opens the door for a discussion rather than an argument. Is there anything else you’d like to work on today?
I think I’m good for now. I just want to keep improving.
That’s a great mindset to have. Remember, progress takes time, and you’re doing well. Let’s check in on your mindfulness practice next session and see how your communication goes with your husband.
Thank you, Ellie. I appreciate your help!
You’re welcome! I’m looking forward to hearing about your progress. Take care, and see you next time!
Bye!
